loans.name: Barikissou Akankè

texts.fr: T. Barikissou Akankè est née le 30/12/1975 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Barikissou Akankè est mariée à AHOUNOU Raoul. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et encore à sa charge. Barikissou Akankè a étudié jusqu'au secondaire mais actuellement, elle est dans le commerce. Barikissou Akankè est en effet dans la quincaillerie. Barikissou Akankè vend ses articles dans une boutique sise au quartier Sènadé de Cotonou. Mais, Barikissou Akankè vit avec sa famille à Suru-Léré toujours à Cotonou. Barikissou Akankè participe aux charges de la famille grâce au revenu de son activité. Barikissou Akankè achète ses articles au Nigeria, État voisin du Bénin. Barikissou Akankè a déjà bénéficié d'un prêt de ALIDé pour le compte de son activité, qu'elle a bien remboursé. Pour continuer de développer son activité, Barikissou Akankè sollicite un deuxième crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Barikissou Akanke T. was born on December 30, 1972 in Cotonou, the Capital city of Benin. Barikissou Akanke is married to Raoul Ahounou. The couple have five children and they are all going to school and they are all still in their care. Barikissou Akanke completed high school but currently she is running a business. Barikissou Akanke runs a hardware store. Barikissou Akanke sells her products in a store located in the Senade district of Cotonou. But Barikissou Akanke lives with her family in the Suru-Lere district of Cotonou. Barikissou Akanke is able to provide for her family thanks to the revenues from her business. Barikissou Akanke purchases items for resale in Nigeria, a neighboring country of Benin. In the past Barikissou Akanke has had a loan from Alide (Kiva Field Partner) to benefit her business, and she repaid it on time. In order to continue to develop her business, Barikissou Akanke is requesting a second loan from Alide, to replenish the working capital funds.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hardware store items ( Achat d'articles de quincaillerie (locks, keys, door handles, etc.)

texts.en: A. Monica is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 42 years old and married with 3 children that are in secondary and primary schools. Monica has a drug shop in Ibanda Main Street that she has been operating for over 7 years and being that it is strategically positioned in the town centre, she is able to attract more customers hence more profits. Monica has a dream of transforming her drug shop into a wholesale shop so that she could be able to make more sales. She needs a loan to help restock her drug shop with more medicines for malaria, and other minor illnesses to avoid shortages. She is such a determined and hard working lady.

loans.use: Restocking her drug shop with more drugs.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe A. is 57 years of age and she is still single, she doesn't want to get married because of poverty, she's with her mother and father and their age is already in the level of 95 years old above, and then she decided to have a business particularly in vegetable vending. They are currently residing at Culing Centro, a rural and plain area,500 meters away from the national highway of Cabatuan. Her vegetable plantation is at the back of their house. 
Her weekly net income is PHP 1,000.00, her source of income is vegetable farming and vending. She struggles for the sake of her family, and sacrifices all what she have, for her father and mother. She applied a loan amount of PHP 6,000.00 for her additional capital. She hopes that KIVA will grant her loan immediately, to support her mother and father.

loans.name: Mrs. Norn Horng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
A village bank loan which consists of thirteen people is located in Kdei Tnaot village in Takeo province and all the members will use the loan in different purposes. Mrs. Norn H. is the village bank president. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder. Since her breeding pigs business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig food for breeding. Now she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and she would use the rest of money to buy fertilizer to support the rice field. Mrs. Norn H. is 41 years old widow with two children who are attending the local school. There are two person who are group guarantee and they are also shown in the picture.  
All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more piglets, pig food, and she would use the rest of money to buy fertilizer to support the rice field.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is 48 years of age. She manages a used-clothing business and she is also a vegetable vendor. Her weekly net income in the clothing sector is 300.00 Philippine pesos, while she also nets another PHP 300.00 per week from vegetable vending. She seeks the loan amount of PHP 8,000.00 from Kiva lenders for use as additional capital for her businesses. 

Estrella is married to Henry C., a farmer. For every crop season, they earn an income amounting to PHP 5,000.00. They also raise four cows on their farm. They are blessed with four children: Joey, 29, who is a technician in their barangay (neighborhood); Henry Jr., a 27-year-old farmer; Henny, 25, who works abroad as a timekeeper; and Ednalyn, 24, who is a housekeeper in metro Manila. 

Estrella describes their village as a peaceful and friendly barangay. Most of the people living in their area are businessmen/businesswomen.

loans.use: Additional capital for her clothing business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca sells provisions and foodstuffs. She is 65 years old and married with 7 children. She has been in business for 4 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N500000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs. She says thanks you to all her kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en: Loveth is 35 years old, and she is married with 4 children. She has a salon where she makes lovely hair styles for her customers.She also sells hair extensions and cream. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Mrs. Meas A. is 54 and currently depends on selling fresh fish at the local busy market. She sells fish that she either gets from her husband’s fishing or buys from her wholesale supplier. Meas A. is a humble, low-income mother who has been blessed with 10 children: four are married and the others are single. Most of her children are employed in various occupations. 

Now the river is full of fish due to the coming fish season and Meas A.’s husband needs more tools for his fishing activities. Meas A. has asked for a loA. to fulfill the business needs of her husband by buying fishing tools.

loans.use: To buy fishing tools for her husband's business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Emiamor

texts.en:
Emiamor R. is 32 years of age, married to Peter R.,who is a tricycle driver and also a farmer. They have three children; Jed Bryan-10 years of age, grade 5 student, John Lester- 6 years old, and their youngest is Kaye Terine- 3 years of age, a preschooler. They are residing harmoniously at San Pablo, Alicia, a rural area, approximately 12 kilometers away from the national highway, she illustrates also their area as peaceful baranggay, and most of the people live there are very industrious. One of their sources of income is farming.
Emiamor manages a hog raising business and her net income in hog raising is PHP 2,000.00 every three months, she wants to avail a loan amount of PHP 12,000.00 to purchase some hog feeds. Aside from hog raising, she is also busy in selling Avon cosmetics products.She believes that patience is one character that we must develop in order to have a productive life.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy hog feeds

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Mom Koy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people who are all living in Kdei Tnaot village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Srey Mom K. is a village bank loan group president who has been selected by the members. They will all use the loan for different purposes. Srey is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Mom Thearen, is an electrician. Mrs. Srey Mom K. is requesting this loan to buy 150 chickens and chicken feed for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living with this loan. She is 23 years old and the mother of a child who is still too young to work or study. 

All the members in this group loan are end-of-term loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Is requesting a loan to buy 150 chickens and chicken food for breeding.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace C. is from the village of Puga-an, Iligan City. She is 37 years old, is married, and has nine school-aged children. Grace owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Puga-an, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Virginie

texts.fr: E. Virginie est née le 09/07/1968. Virginie est mariée à ATCHAMOU Justin, un transitaire au port de Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Virginie est mère de cinq enfants non tous scolarisés et encore à leur charge son mari et elle. Virginie et sa famille vivent à Aglangandan dans la Commune de Sèmè-Kpodji. Virginie a fait seulement le cours primaire puis s'est mise à vendre. Virginie vend en effet des produits vivriers, de charbon de bois et des cartes de recharge téléphonique à son domicile et de façon ambulante. C'est dans les villages environnants de sa Commune que Virginie va s'approvisionner en produits vivriers. Grâce au revenu de son activité, Virginie vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Virginie veut élever le niveau de son activité pour pouvoir se faire plus de revenu. C'est pourquoi Virginie sollicite un prêt de la part de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement afin de mieux développer son activité.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de maïs, de charbon de bois, de tubercules d'igname et cartes de recharge téléphonique.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Mrs. Long Pork Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Long P. is a weaver. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more raw materials. Her husband, Mr. P. Saroeun, is a motorbike taxi driver. This couple has four children: two are weavers, one is employed in a garment factory, and the last one is attending the local school.

Mrs. Long P. is the village bank president. This village bank consists of 20 people located in Trapeang Veaeng village in Takeo province. The members will use their loans for different purposes. Ten members of this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. EoT loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchasing more raw materials

loans.name: Hoy

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoy V., 47, is a duck-egg trader. She is a widow and the mother of seven children of whom five are married and live away from home and the other two are single. Two of her children are employed: her son sells pots to earn a living and her daughter is a garment worker.

Presently, Hoy V. sells eggs that she buys in bulk from suppliers. She is facing a problem with transportation; she also pays a lot of money for her traveling expenses. Therefore, Hoy V. requests a loan to buy a motorcycle which she will use to transport her product to the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to transport her product to market

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
“The best prize that life offers is the chance to work hard at work worth doing” says Marilyn G. the loving wife of Marlon G.. They live harmoniously with only one child at Barangay Parog-Parog Solana, Cagayan. They are blessed with only one gifted child who is four years old now, a kindergarten pupil in their village. The couple strives to work hard in order that they can send their only one child in school to finish a degree course in order that someday she has a bright future.


Marilyn is also a hog raiser in their village, aside from managing their rice field. Furthermore, she cultivates their farm by planting rice and some vegetables together with her husband. She is now requesting a loan of PHP17,000 as additional farming capital to develop her rice farming business which provides her family with an adequate supply of food and assists them in maintaining their pig raising business.

loans.use: additonal capital for her farming business

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha C. is from the village of Argayoso, Manticao, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Martha owns and operates a variety store, selling a variety of basic needs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2005, Martha joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. Martha is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 10th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Mrs. Saratt Suon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The village bank loan which consists of nineteen people and they all live in Trapeang Veaeng village Takeo province. Mrs. Saratt S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a Khmer noodle seller. Her husband, Mr. Chuon Pouv, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He is also a construction worker. In his plantation, he faces an obstacle because his field is infertile soil. Thus, Mrs. Saratt S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice to make the crop more productive. She is 39 years old and the mother of four children, two of whom are enrolled in the local school and the others are too young to work or study. Mrs. Channy S. did not come to take a loan but her husband was, so he was presented in the picture instead. 
Twelve members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the rice to make the crop more productive.

loans.name: Zainah

texts.en: Zainah is 43 year single mother of four children aged between 13 and 20 years. All her children go to school .She resides and owns a three roomed house where she stays with five people  Zainah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water. Zainah works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala.  She owns a stall selling bananas and buys these bananas from villages of Masaka.  She pays transport costs to and from shopping. She is faced with the challenge of increasing prices of bananas due droughts which hit most parts of Uganda. Zainah sells to all categories of people both on retail and whole sale and works seven days a week .  She has been in this banana business for fifteen years and with MCDT for six years servicing her twelfth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning an established deport for bananas

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeurn S., a 46-year-old widow with two children, runs a small grocery store in her house. Aside from this business, she owns a piece of land to cultivate rice and she is a duck breeder. Since her poultry business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more ducklings and duck feed.

Mrs. Soeurn S. lives in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo province. One of her children is attending the local school and the other one helps with his mother’s business.

loans.use: To purchase more ducklings and duck feed

loans.name: Math

texts.en:
Mrs. Math S. resides in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. There, she owns a small business, selling ice blocks to her villagers for a profit. Her husband is San Salos, age 59, who has a small garage at home where he provides a washing and repairing services. This older couple has four children, two of whom are car taxi drivers and the others are unemployed.

Math S. is applying for a loan for her husband to use as capital to improve his business in order to satisfy the needs of his customers.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her husband's garage

loans.name: Analie

texts.en:
Analie C. is from the village of Poblacion, Iligan City. She is 38 years old. She is separated from her spouse and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Analie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The primary source of income for the business comes from selling food & daily use products in the local community. Analie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Analie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI, and is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Analie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Poblacion, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Naem

texts.en: Mrs. Naem N. is a villager in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. In this farming, she now has a problem because she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers to support the field so she decided to buy them for the purpose. Her husband, Mr. In Hul, is a teacher who can make a small salary for his family. Mrs. Naem N. has three children two of whom are attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of five years old. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support the field

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is 53 year married with eight children aged between 8 and 37 years. Three of her children go to school .She resides and rents a two roomed house where she stays with seven people  Jane takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water.  Jane works in semi urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala.  She owns a stall selling honey in Owino market and buys her honey from suppliers who get it from villages .  She pays transport costs to and from home. She is faced with the challenge of increasing prices of honey in Uganda.  She pay rent for her business premises at 50000/= per month and daily market dues of 300/=. Jane sells to all categories of people both on retail and whole sale and works six days a week .  She has been in this honey business for three years and with MCDT for five years servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of honey  .  She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and owning an established business and a deport for Honey suppliers

loans.use: To buy more jerrycans of Honey

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Igbinovia

texts.en: Igbinovia is 32 years old and he is single without children. He sells building materials to make a living within his community in Benin city, Edo state, Nigeria. He hopes for the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim C. is from the village of Poblacion, Manticao Misamis Oriental. She is 38 years old. Kim is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Kim owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Kim has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Kim joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Kim is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Kim from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is 43 years old and married with six children aged between 12 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with seven people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Jesca works in a semi-urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a stall in Owino market selling cassava which she buys from suppliers who get it from villages. She sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale, and works six days a week. She pays transport costs to and from home. She doesn’t pay rent for her business premises but only pays daily market dues of 500/=.

Jesca is faced with the challenge of increasing prices of food due to droughts in many parts of Uganda.

Jesca has been in this business for three years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her tenth loan and working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of cassava and potatoes. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and to owning an established business.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of cassava and potatoes

loans.name: Mouv

texts.en:
Mrs. Mouv S. is a farmer who owns a 2 hectare field. She now faces a small problem, because she does not have enough money to hire a laborer to plow the field. She decided to ask for a loan to hire a laborer for her farm. She will use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and a pump to make her field more productive.

Mrs. Mouv S. lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. Her husband, Mr. Leong Chea, is a construction worker who makes a small income to support the family. They have two children: one is employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. Mrs. Mouv S. and her husband are in the photo.

loans.use: To hire a laborer to plow the field and to buy fertilizers, pesticides and a pump

loans.name: Toeng

texts.en: Toeng S., aged 51, is a married woman blessed with five children. Four of them are married and have already started new homes, while the other one is single and employed in the garment industry. She sells a variety of cakes, which her husband produces, in front of a factory for garment workers. After Toeng S. finishes selling, she goes to buy her essential ingredients at the market for her husband to make more cakes. Her sales are going well because her customers recognize the good quality of her cakes. To make her business more successful, Toeng S. is looking for a loan to enlarge her business.

loans.use: to enlarge her business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 42 years old and widowed with ten children aged between 13 and 30 years. Six of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she lives with seven people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Florence works in a semi-urban area which in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a bar selling all brands of beers and local drinks and buys these beers from delivery vans and local ones from her suppliers. She doesn’t pay transport costs to and from shopping because she buys from her home. She sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale and works seven days a week.

Florence’s home acts both as her residence and business place. She has been in this bar business for twenty years and with MCDT for one year, servicing her third loan and working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerrycans of local gin and crates of beer.

Florence aspires to seeing her business grow bigger and to owning an established guest house.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local brew

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita has been selling second hand clothes since 1998.She hopes to own a boutique in the future.She hopes for the loan amount of N70,000 to purchase more second hand clothes to sell.She is 40 years old and married with 4 children.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more second hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 45-year-old married woman with four children aged between 19 and 23 years. All her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with seven people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Margaret works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a stall in Owino market where she sells secondhand clothes, buying her clothes from the very same market. She sells to all categories of people both in retail and wholesale and works six days a week. She pays transport costs to and from home. Besides this clothing business, she also plaits ladies’ hair.

Margaret is faced with the challenge of the increasing prices of secondhand clothes in Uganda. She pays rent for her business premises at 50,000/= per month and daily market dues of 1,000/=. She has been in this clothing business for three years and with MCDT for five years, servicing her tenth loan and working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more secondhand clothes.

Margaret is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning an established home.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Paort

texts.en: Mr. Paort K., a resident of Andoung Samrith village in Takeo Province, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land upon which he cultivates rice. Because he does not have enough money to buy a pump to water the field, he is requesting a loan for this purpose as well as to buy fertilizers and hire a laborer to plow the field. Mr. Paort K., single, lives with his parents.

loans.use: To buy a water pump and fertilizers and hire a laborer to plow the field

loans.name: Galsandorj

texts.en:
Galsandorj U. is a 31-year-old married woman living in Hovd province, one of Mongolia's western provinces. She lives with her family and three children. Her two children go to a local secondary school and the youngest son goes to a local kindergarten. U. drives a cab in the town. She first purchased a small car in 2008 and has been using her car as a cab.

As the city authority has recently introduced city buses for locals, the taxi business has gotten more competitive. U. now works harder and more hours in order not to lose her daily income from her taxi business. After this winter, she hopes to sell her old car and purchase a better cost-efficient and fuel-efficient Japanese car for her business. She says that with the new Japanese car, she can reduce repair and maintenance costs as well as fuel costs.

For now, she requests a loan to purchase second-hand spare parts for her old car.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand spare parts for her old car

loans.name: Mien

texts.en: Mrs. Mien N., a farmer living in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo Province, owns a 2-hectare field upon which she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Touch Thea, presented in the picture with her, is a cow breeder, and since this business is going well, he wants to buy two more cows. His wife is therefore requesting a loan  for this purpose. The couple has one child, three years of age.

loans.use: To buy two more cows for breeding.

loans.name: Genie

texts.en:
This is Genie T., 56-year-old store owner from Tala, Caloocan City. She has four grown-up children. Her husband Roel, 59, is a government employee.

Genie has been in business for twelve years already. She manages her own sari-sari (general) store located at their house. On a daily basis, she makes more than P 1,000. She saves most of her profits in preparation for her husband’s retirement from work.

In 2005, she came to know the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and eventually became a member. She enjoys attending its weekly meetings for women entrepreneurs. Genie has applied for a new loan with the cooperative in the amount of P 24,000 as additional capital for her store.

Genie says she couldn’t ask for more because all her children are already independently working for themselves. She has all her time to attend to her husband and her store.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Genden

texts.en: Genden E. is a 40-year-old who lives with his wife and two teenage children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His eldest daughter goes to a university in Hoh Hot, China. She is a second-year student in the local Chinese university. His youngest son is a student in a local secondary school in Ulaanbaatar. E. sells motorcycles as well as their accessories and spare parts in the auto-market in Ulaanbaatar. He imports various motorcycles from China and retails them at a profit in Ulaanbaatar. He says that his business has been good since its start and is the main source of his family income. He further says that he would like to expand his motorcycle business and continue paying his daughter's school tuition in China. He requests a loan to purchase more motorcycle accessories and spare parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more motorcycle accessories and spare parts for his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional cloth in bulk.

loans.name: Nambar

texts.en:
S. is 21 years old and lives with his wife and one-year-old daughter in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is a university student and looks after their daughter at home. S. operates an ice cream and soft drink manufacturing business which was started by his father in 1996.

When the business was first started 13 years ago, the working capital was approximately 100,000 tugrug (~70 USD) but he and his father worked hard and today the working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD). S. took over the business in 2009 after his father retired and he wants to eventually build a small factory where he can produce more of his ice cream and soft drinks.

He works hard to improve his family’s quality of life and grow his small business. S. is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan in order to purchase supplies for his growing business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for his growing ice cream and soft drink business

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas V. is 50 years of age and currently lives in Phnom Penh, the capital Cambodia. Meas V. owns a small place located in front of garment industry, where she is selling well with her dessert business. She typically generates an income of $4 a day to contribute her family’s daily living. She is a widow mother who has given birth to four children. Three of her daughters are employed: two are food servers for a company and one is a sewing worker for garment factory. Meas V. is taking out her loan to expand her current business. This loan will provide her with additional income and a standard of her family’s living.

loans.use: To expand her current business

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en: Mrs. Sophea H. is a villager in Andoung Samrith village in Takeo province. She is a rice farmer who owns 2-hectar field to cultivate rice to earn for living. She now faces a small problem because her field is infertile soil which affect to her crop so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive and she would use the rest of the loan to buy ducks and duck food for her husband, Mr. Ut Sophon, who is a duck breeder. Mrs. Sophea H. has four children one of whom is a driver and others two are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is on the age of four years old. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy  fertilizers, ducks and duck food.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is 41 years old and married with 2 children. She sells groceries. She is requesting for the loan amount of N80, 000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery to sell

loans.name: Handsuren

texts.en:
Handsuren N. is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two older children are university students and her youngest daughter attends a local secondary school. Her husband is a driver and operates a taxi service in their town.

N. manages a clothing business in her town. She sells a variety of clothing items that are imported from China. N. started her clothing business in 1999 with capital of 20,000 tugrugs (~14 USD). At first she only sold second-hand clothes, but after growing her business over the years, her success has enabled her to purchase and sell new clothes.

Today, her working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD) For the future, N. hopes to continue to grow her business and says, "I hope to one day own my own workplace." She is requesting a 1,700,000 tugrug (~1200 USD) loan to purchase more clothes in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes in order to expand her business

loans.name: Victoriana

texts.en:
Victoriana M., 50 years old, is a happy mother of nine children. Her husband Teoducio drives for a living. They live in Caloocan City. She owns and manages a sari-sari (general) store just in front of their house. She started this in 2003 and has slowly grown it to what it is now. She earns P 500 a day.

Joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in February of this year helped her business stay afloat despite stiff competition. Victoriana applied for a new loan in the amount of P 8,000 to purchase more items to sell. She is now on her 3rd loan cycle.

Like most general store owners, it is also her dream to own a large grocery store someday.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items to sell at her store

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Mrs. Sam O., born in 1982, lives in Andoung Samrith village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer and her husband, Mr. Ben Nem, presented in the photo with her, is a duck breeder. Since the latter business is going well, Mrs. Sam O. is requesting a loan to buy more ducks for breeding  as well as additional duck food. The couple has three children, two of whom are attending the local school, while the youngest, just three years old, is yet too young to study.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for breeding as well as additional duck food.

loans.name: Gansukh

texts.en: S. is 28 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in the Uvurkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife stays home and takes care of their children. S. operates a computer service business where he does computer repairs and maintenance. He began his business in 2005 and since then he has gained a good reputation amongst his customers. S. would like to eventually have his own computer retail store so that he can expand his customer base and his profits. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan in order to purchase computers and computer parts for his business.

loans.use: To purchase computers and computer parts for his business

loans.name: Ilyne

texts.en:
This loan is for Ilyne who is a direct seller of MSE, NATASHA, SUNDANCE, and AVON products (all of those products are cosmetics or apparel); her weekly net income is PHP 1,000. She has applied for a loan in the amount of PHP 6,000 for additional requirements and to purchase some personal collection to sell in their village again.

Ilyne hopes that KIVA lenders will approve her loan as soon as possible to finance her son's medication. Ilyne is a widow, a loving mother, whose child is Ryan Caine- 20 years of age, 3rd year college student. Unfortunately her son did not continue his education this first semester, because of asthma. He is under medication right now, and maybe next year he will be able to continue his education. She describes her village as quite productive; most of the people there are employed and busy.

loans.use: additional capital for her direct sales business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Florence

texts.fr: A. Florence est mariée à TANDJI Dénis, un professeur. Florence et Dénis ont deux enfants tous scolarisés et encore à leur charge. La famille vit à Aglangandan dans la Commune de Sèmè-Kpodji depuis sept ans environ. Florence est coiffeuse mais elle vend également des produits de cheveux et de beauté à une clientèle de plus en plus importante. Florence à son salon de coiffure devant son chez. C'est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Florence s'approvisionne en ses différents produits. Florence a déjà dix ans d'expérience dans la coiffure et la vente de produits de cheveux. Aussi, Florence a eu de ALIDé trois crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu élever le niveau de son service et de son activité. Pour renforcer son fonds de roulement afin de mieux répondre à la demande de sa cliente, Florence sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé.

loans.use: Achat de produits cheveux et de beauté.

loans.name: Ngozi

texts.en: Ngozi sells second hand clothes in retail. She is 35 years old and married with 3 children. She is hoping for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase second hand clothes to sell. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase second hand clothes

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. Pov M., a farmer living in Mea Neak village in Takeo Province, owns 5 hectares of land upon which she cultivates rice.  Because she does not have enough money to buy more rice seeds to cultivate, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Vy Chhaem, is a fisherman who can make a small income to support the family. The couple has two children, one attending the local school while the other, three years of age, is yet too young to study.

loans.use: To buy more rice seeds to cultivate

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her business

loans.name: Srey Yi

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Yi H. and her husband, Mr. Pen Yang, are duck breeders. They live in Mea Neak village in Takeo province. They have two children:  one helps with the business and the other one is attending the local school. Since their business is going well, they want to expand it. Therefore, Mrs. Srey Yi H. decided to ask for a loan to buy 160 ducks.

loans.use: To buy 160 ducks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of commodities in bulk.

loans.name: Gliceria

texts.en:
Gliceria G., 58 years old, is a successful businesswoman from Malaria, Tala, Caloocan City. She is married to Policarpo, also a businessman. They have five children.

Gliceria has a fairly large general store where she sells grocery items and rice. Her husband also manages their own clothing store. Both businesses have been in existence for ten years now. Gliceria is earning more than P30,000 a month.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2004. The loans provided by the cooperative are quite helpful in sustaining her businesses. She is now applying for a new loan in the amount of P 24,000 as additional capital for her businesses. This will be her 14th loan cycle with CCT.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy is 36 years old and married with 5 children. She sells cooking oil to make a living. This is the high season for sales and she wants to take advantage of it to increase her profits. She is hoping for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more cooking oil to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase milk storage versels.

loans.name: Akuvi

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants. Pour aider financièrement son mari dans l’éducation scolaire de leurs enfants, elle s’est lancée en 1998 dans la vente de certains produits d’alimentation générale en particulier du maïs, du riz, de la farine de manioc, de l’huile raffinée et certains condiments de cuisine; elle exerce ce commerce dans sa maison, dans une boutique de vente. Son activité se situe dans le quartier de Dabarakondji à Lomé. Grâce à cette activité, elle apporte sa contribution financière à son mari dans la gestion du foyer. En ce moment, elle voudrait renouveler son stock ; pour cela elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter, 05 sacs de riz, 05 sacs de maïs, 02 bidons d’huile de 25 litres et des condiments pour la cuisine.

loans.use: Achat des produits d'alimentation générale

loans.name: Seik

texts.en: Mrs. Seik O. was born in 1969 and she lives in Andoung Samrith village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectar field to cultivate rice to earn for living. She is a widow with four children two of whom are duck breeders and another one is attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is on the age of three years old. Since breeding duck is going well, Mrs. Seik O. decided to ask for a loan to buy more 400-duck for breeding and she would use the rest of the loan duck food for her poultry business.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more 400-duck for breeding and she would use the rest of the loan duck food for her poultry business.

loans.name: Atiwassa Veronique

texts.fr: Cette femme vend des denrées alimentaires ou des produits d’alimentation générale comme activité génératrice de revenu. C’est en 2006  qu’elle s’est lancée dans ce commerce qui lui permet désormais d’apporter sa contribution financière dans la gestion du foyer. Elle vend des œufs, des tomates en boîtes, du haricot et même des bonbons. Elle vend au bord d’un boulevard très fréquenté dans le quartier de Tokoin Wuiti à Lomé. En ce moment elle souhaite avoir un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des articles manquants dans son stock ; ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter 01 carton d’allumettes, 02 sacs de haricots, 10 plateaux d’œufs, 15 cartons de tomates et des boîtes de biscuits. Elle est mariée et mère d’un enfant.

loans.use: Achat des produits d'alimentation générale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional hair products

loans.name: Adrienne

texts.fr: Z. Adrienne est mariée à SESSON Jean, un chauffeur. Adrienne et Jean ont trois enfants tous scolarisés et encore à leur charge. La famille vit à Pk10 dans la Commune de Sèmè-Kpodji. Adrienne vend de l'huile d'arachide qu'elle distribue à sa clientèle tantôt à crédit tantôt elle est payée en cash. Adrienne va s'approvisionner en huile d'arachide à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est depuis cinq ans que Adrienne est dans la vente de l'huile d'arachide. Pour cette activité, Adrienne a eu déjà trois crédits de la part de ALIDé. Adrienne a bien remboursé ces trois crédits et en sollicite un quatrième aujourd'hui pour mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.

loans.use: Achat d'huile d'arachide.

loans.name: Henry

texts.en: Henry is 40 years old and married with 3 children. He is an electrician and he also sells electrical materials. He specializes in the repair of television sets. He is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more electrical materials to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her business.

loans.name: Améyo Akpédzé

texts.fr: Cette dame est gérante d’un débit de boisson à Lomé. Son bar est très visité par de nombreux clients qui apprécient la propreté de ce bar. Elle est mariée et est mère d’un enfant. Elle a le sens des affaires, ce qui fait qu’elle réalise de bonnes affaires et a des atouts pour bien accueillir ses clients. Elle vend non seulement de la bière, mais aussi du vin, des liqueurs et des cannettes de boissons. Son bar est situé à un bon endroit et est  facilement visible et accessible. Pour faire des provisions et éviter une éventuelle rupture de stocks, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des casiers de bières et sucreries, 12 cartons de vins et divers autres produits. Elle a une réelle conviction qu’elle honorera sans problèmes ses engagements de remboursement.

loans.use: Achat de sasiers de boissons, de vins et cannettes

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
This is Carmelita M., 23 years old, a young plastic wares dealer from Sta. Rita South, Tala, Caloocan City. She has one child.

Carmelita sells modular cabinets made of plastic, in various places, with her husband. She has been doing this for six years already. She is earning P 12,000 a month. Carmelita saves most of her profits for the future of her child.

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. Now on her 7th loan cycle, she has applied for a new loan in the amount of P8,000 as additional capital for her business. She dreams of having a larger plastic ware store where she can sell furniture as well.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng S. N. is a married woman and a 56 years old and resides in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia her birth place. She currently sells vegetables that she buys in bulk them from farmers. She has been a vegetable trader for years and is earning an average of $4 per day. As another source of family income, who drivers a motorbike taxi. She has five children: two are married and live independently and others are single and they work sewing clothe for a factory. Heng S. N. will be using her loan to sustain her business growth.

loans.use: To sustain her business growth

loans.name: Isaiah

texts.en: Isaiah is 36 years old and he is single without children. He sells crates of drinks. He is requesting the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un cordonnier de profession. En 1994, il a ouvert son atelier de fabrication et de réparation de chaussure dans le quartier de Tokoin Forever à Lomé. Il est très expérimenté et a toujours su répondre aux désirs de sa clientèle. Beaucoup de personnes admirent son sens de créativité et d’adaptation. Il fabrique aussi des chaussures qu’il revend ensuite. Ses chaussures sont faites en peaux de cuir. C’est pour acheter tous les éléments nécessaires à la confection de chaussures qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES ; le prêt servira à acheter des peaux de cuir, de la colle, des doublures et divers éléments indispensables. Il est marié et a 02 enfants à sa charge.

loans.use: Achat de peaux de cuir, de la colle et doublures

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of ingredients

loans.name: Mr. Chorn Uorng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of seventeen people, is located I. Trea Village I. Kandal province. Mr. Chorn U. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. All the members will use the loan for different purposes.

Mr. Chorn U. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which he cultivates rice to earn a living. On his farm, he now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy fertilizer to support the field. So he decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizer to support the field and to make his crop more productive.

Mr. Chorn U. is 53 years old and his wife, Mrs. N. Srey Pov, helps him on the plantation. They have two children, one of whom is employed I. a garment factory while the other is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to make his crop more productive

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Lil Joy

texts.en:
For almost four years, Lil Joy has operated a chicken, frozen products and fish selling business at a public market. Her weekly net income is PHP 1,000.00. She has also had a retail store for almost ten years and a livestock business of hog raising. She is asking for a loan of PHP 23,000.00 from KIVA lenders in order to have additional working capital to buy more chicken to sell.

She is married to Eliseo, a principal at Culing Centro National High School. They are blessed with three children: Kristel Joy- 22 years of age, a college graduate; Krisha Eloisa - 17 years of age, a second year college student, and their youngest, Kristan Ryne - 5 years of age, a preschooler. They are currently residing at Culing Sentro, two kilometers away from the national highway. She hopes and prays that KIVA lenders will grant her the loan to allow her to meet her family needs and to support the education of their children.

loans.use: To buy more chicken meat.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is 43 years old and married with 3 children. She sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, yams, etc. She is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ama Lébéne

texts.fr: Cette femme n’est pas mariée mais a un enfant à sa charge. C’est pour cette raison que l’année dernière, elle s’est lancée dans la vente d’huiles de palme (huile rouge) dans le marché de Hédzranawoé à Lomé. La plupart de ses clients apprécient la qualité et la bonne odeur que dégagent ses huiles. Elle met les huiles dans les bouteilles d’eau minérale et les revend ensuite. Elle prévoit dans l’avenir agrandir encore plus son commerce en vendant aussi des produits d’alimentation générale. Pour renouveler en ce moment son stock en baisse, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 litres d’huile rouge.
texts.en:
This is a woman who is not married but has one child to support.  For this reason last year, she started selling palm oil (red oil) at the Hédzranawoé market in Lomé.  Most of her customers appreciate the quality and the nice aroma of her oils.  She puts the oils into mineral water bottles and then resells them.  In the future, she foresees expanding her commerce once more by selling grocery items as well.  To renew her low inventory right now, she's requesting a WAGES loan to buy 20 liters of red oil.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy palm oils

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: S. N. is a married woman and a 45 years old and resides in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia her birth place. Khan Sim currently sells vegetables that she grows them on her own land in the village. Usually, S. N. needs to wait three month times later before harvesting and selling her mature crop. She has four children: two are married and live independently and others are single and are working as garment workers. S. N. will be using the half of her loan to buy more vegetable seeds to grow and the rest to buy an old motorbike which she will use for her family's riding needs.

loans.use: To buy more vegetable seeds to grow and the rest to buy an old motorbike which she will use for her family's riding needs

loans.name: Estrelita

texts.en:
This is Estrelita E., a young entrepreneur from Pangarap, Caloocan City. She is 34 years-old. Her husband Jonathan, 32, is a street vendor. Three of their five children are already in grade school.

Estrelita owns and manages a general store which she started ten years ago. She sells small toys and fun items for kids. She earns P12,000.00 a month.

She has applied for a loan with Kiva Partner the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in the amount of P12,000.00 in order to provide additional capital for her business to purchase new toy designs. It has been Lilia’s dream for a long time to eventually have her own toy store in a big shopping mall.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase new toys.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is married to Gregorio P. who works as a farmer. They are blessed with two 18 year-old twin girls Ma. Theresa, a second year college student, and Ma. Elena. They live in Culing Centro Cabatuan, Isabela, a rural and plain area and their house is located near the national highway.

Cristina manages a business selling cosmetics and herbal medicines and her weekly net income is PHP 500.00. She is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000.00 from KIVA lenders to provide additional capital for her business. She hopes that KIVA lenders will grant her loan in order to allow her to support her family and the education of their children for a fruitful future.

loans.use: To provide additional capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: God Time Group

texts.en:
God Time is a group of five borrowers led by Isatta K..  Isatta is 49 years-old and married with a 25 year-old child with an educational level of the eleventh grade.  Isatta is illiterate due to the fact that most Muslim parents in Liberia when she was growing up could not send their girl children to school. 
She and her family live in Virginia but she works in the Dualla market, the largest food market north of the capital, Monrovia, Liberia 

Isatta's business is selling prepared food. She buys food and cooking materials such as rice, oil, seasoning, charcoal and vegetables and sells the well prepared food plates in the market.  She has had this business for 20 years and hopes to establish a large restaurant in the future.  Isatta's delicious food is affordable and she talks to her customers in a friendly manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Unfortunately, she faces difficulties in the rainy season because when it rains there are fewer customers.

Isatta is seeking a loan in order to purchase rice, seasoning cubes, oil, vegetables etc. in order to cook more food to serve her customers. Isatta dreams of improving her and her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhom Chhun Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nineteen people who live in Trea village in Kandal province are made up the village bank and they will use the loan which they obtained in different purposes. Mrs. Sokhom C. is a village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns 0.8-hectar to cultivate rice to earn for a living. In this farming, she now has a problem because her field is infertile soil so it is affected o the crop. To deal with this problem, Mrs. Sokhom C. decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Thaong Samon, is a teacher who can make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sokhom C. is 48 years old and the mother of three children two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is attending the local school. All the members are presented in the picture but some of them are block.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive.

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr: Cet homme est marié et a 02 enfants à sa charge. Il est chauffeur de taxi de profession ; mais parallèlement à cette activité, il s’est lancé depuis 2006 dans le commerce de charbon de bois dans le quartier de Bè à Lomé. Il a recruté une personne pour l’aider dans cette tâche. Il vend aussi certains produits d’alimentation générale comme de l’eau minérale, des boissons et divers produits. Il dispose aussi d’une boutique de vente d’appareils cellulaires et d’autres accessoires. Il sollicite un crédit de WAGES en ce moment pour remplacer certains de ses produits manquants. Le prêt lui permettra d’acheter 10 sacs de charbon de bois, 15 cartons d’eau minérale Pure Water, 50 bouteilles de boissons de toute sorte et d’autres accessoires de téléphones portables.

loans.use: Achat de sacs de charbon de bois, de cartons d'eau minérale et accessoires de téléphones portables

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo is still single and, with four family members, lives with his parents at Culing Centro, Cabatuan, Isabela. Their house is located at National Highway, a rural and plain area.

Alfredo manages a motorcycle transport business, earning a daily net income of from PHP 200 to 300. He applied for a loan of PHP 9,000 to pay for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle.

Alfredo wants to increase his income to support his family needs and to help his nephew's education. He believes that, no matter what happens, he will work hard for his family, even though he has a small business.

loans.use: To pay for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty is 39 years old and married with 6 children. She sells hair extensions and she also makes lovely hair styles for her customers in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria. She is requesting for the loan amount of N80, 000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell.She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Afoussé

texts.fr: Cette dame exerce depuis 2005 le commerce de produits génériques au Grand Marché de Lomé. Grâce à cette activité, elle apporte sa contribution financière dans le foyer pour l’éducation scolaire de leurs 03 enfants. Elle vend aussi bien en gros qu’en détail à des revendeuses ambulantes de ces produits. Elle est connue de beaucoup de clients qui arrivent à trouver dans sa boutique tous les produits dont ils ont besoin. Elle a même des relations d’affaire avec certaines cliniques de Lomé en leur fournissant des médicaments génériques pour leurs patients. Elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES en ce moment pour acheter certains produits manquants dans son stock de médicaments. Elle a l’assurance de tenir ses engaments de remboursement.
texts.en:
Since 2005, this woman has been doing commerce in generic pharmaceutical products at the Grand Market of Lomé.  Thanks to this work, she contributes her financial share to the household to educate their three children.  She also sells wholesale, as well as retail, to itinerant sellers of her goods.  She is known by many customers who manage to find everything they need in her store.  She even has business contacts with certain Lomé clinics, to which she supplies generic pharmaceuticals for their patients.  She's requesting a WAGES loan at this time to buy certain products in short supply in her inventory of medications.  She is confident of keeping her loan repayment obligations. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy generic medications

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock of her business.

loans.name: Chun

texts.en:
Mr. C. is a 42-year-old taxi driver, while his wife stays at home to sell some cooking ingredients to the villagers. This couple now has six single children, most of whom are working as garment workers.

C. is requesting a loan to repair his old house that often has problems. He was not available when the photo was taken so his wife is shown instead.

loans.use: To repair his old house

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita has worked as a vegetable and fruit vendor in their village for almost a year, earning a weekly net income of PHP 250 to 300. She has applied for a loan of PHP 5,000 to use as additional working capital for her business. She works hard for her family, and builds a strong foundation for them to hold on to, no matter what problems may come in their life.

Teresita is married to Jose P., a farmer, and they are blessed with two children namely: Nick - 29 years of age, and Josephine - 20 years of age, both in college. The family lives in Barangay Culing Centro, Cabatuan, Isabela. Their source of income is farming.

Teresita always uses patience in order to perform her tasks, to grow her business and increase her income. She said that "God is the source of everything. When you have a bountiful blessing, you must share with those who are in need."

loans.use: To use as additional working capital for her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Noen Chab Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. NoE. C. is a village bank president who has beE. selected by the members in Peam Ta Aek village in Kandal province.  Mrs. NoE. C. is a tailor in the local village. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loA. to buy more cloths to make clothes for the customers.  She is a widow with three childrE. one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other helps the mother on the current business and the youngest one is attending the local school.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy more cloths to make clothes for the customers.

loans.name: Maria Rita

texts.en: This is Maria Rita R., 43 years old. She lives in Barrio Filipino, Pasay City, with her husband Ronaldo, also 43, and their six children. Maria Rita has a small space near a train station. For more than twenty years already, she has been selling cold drinks and bottled water to busy customers who are mostly day-to-day passengers of the commuter train. She earns P1,800 per day. Maria Rita became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She is now applying for a loan of P13,000 for the continued operation of her business. In the future, Maria Rita wants to see all her children successfully finish their education. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria G., who lives in the village of Barangay Himaya, Hinigaran, Negros Occidental, is 50 years old. She is married to Mario G., who is presently working as an elected barangay (village) councilor and who is also a farmer and a team supervisor in a sugarcane plantation. The couple have seven children: their eldest daughter already has a family, and the six younger children are still studying. Even though Maria's husband has work and does odd jobs for additional income, the money he earns is still not enough to support the needs of seven children. Maria strives hard to help her husband earn additional income for the family and to sustain the educational needs of their children. To help her husband, Maria started a fish-vending business, selling fish to households in her community and other neighboring villages. The income she earned went mostly to the support of her children's education. In 2003, when she wanted to expand her business, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could borrow additional capital without putting up any collateral. Because of her good credit performance, Maria was able to get incrementally bigger loans over the next loan cycles. From the loans and from her increased income, she was able to put up a "sari-sari" or general store and have another source of income. As she continued borrowing and paying off her loans at NWTF-Project Dungganon without any delays, her business ventures have gradually stabilized and now earn a monthly net income of PHP 3,000 for her family. For her previous loan, she borrowed Php 17,000 as additional working capital for her fish vending and general store businesses and the loan was fully paid on time without any delays in any of her her weekly payments. Now, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing the same amount of Php 17,000 for her two businesses. The income from this will, as usual, be be saved for her children’s education. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her businesses

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She sells provisions and foodstuffs. She is requesting for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuff to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and foodstuffs

loans.name: Bravo Plus Group

texts.fr: Annie M. 41 ans, est une femme qui est dans la micro-entreprise depuis 1996. Elle a acquit une solide expérience dans ce domaine qui lui permet de bien gérer son activité. Elle vend de haricots et de l’huile de palme et végétale dans un quartier montagneux situé à l’ouest de Kinshasa. Annie est cliente fidèle de l’IMF HOPE RDC qui lui a déjà prêté 4 fois les crédits qu’elle a remboursés correctement. C’est grâce à ces crédits que son affaire a prospéré. Elle compte avec le prochain prêt renforcer le stock de sa marchandise en achetant de haricots dans le but d’accroitre son capital et répondre au besoin de ses clients. Annie est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 4 et 18 ans. Quatre d’entre eux sont scolarisés.
texts.en:
Annie M. is 41 years old. She has been a small-business woman since 1996. She has acquired some solid experience in the field and she is able to manage her business well. She sells beans and plam and vegetable oils in a mountainous district located west of Kinshasa. Annie is a loyal client of IMF Hope RDC (Kiva Field Partner), and the organisation has already disbursed 4 loans in the past, all of which she has repaid on time. Her business has prospered thanks to these loans. Her next loan will be used to resupply her stocks of merchandise, especially with the purchase of beans. Her goal is to increase her revenues and to meet client demands. Annie is married and she is the mother of 5 children, they are aged between 4 and 18 years of age. Four of her kids are going to school.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To resupply her stock of merchandise, to purchase a sack of beans.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Melogin

texts.en: Melogin Y., 39 years old, has been selling different foodstuffs (snacks, crackers, chips, and bottled drinks) on side streets for the last twenty years. Her husband, Rene, 41, is a fellow street-vendor. All their four children are in different school levels: the eldest is in college, the next is in high school, and the two youngest are in grade school. Melogin’s place of business is situated in a bustling area – right at the foot of a commuter train station. Her business is going well because of its strategic location. She enjoys her business very much because commuters always need something to munch and drink and she’s happy that she can provide what they need. She is now earning P28,000 a month. Melogin’s small space always falls victim to frequent clearing operations done by the City Hall operatives. That’s why she’s been saving a lot so she could afford to have a permanent space for her business. She currently needs a loan of P21,000 for the expansion of her business. Melogin became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative only last year. What she likes most about her fellowship group is the level of trust and camaraderie amongst all the members. In the future, Melogin hopes to see all her children finish their education. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To use as additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Almar

texts.en:
Almar M. is from the village of Danao. He is 19 years old. Almar is single. To make a living, Almar owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Almar is just starting this business.

In 2009, Almar joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Almar is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Almar from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.
